Today is my granddaughter 's second birthday
I think about this a lot
we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes
I want us to invest in you
I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business
We also have to make the economy fairer
That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee , finally , equal pay for women 's work
I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

cqs.reason: This question challenges the speaker's assumption that investing in specific sectors will directly lead to job creation and income growth.
cqs.cq: How does Clinton plan to ensure that investing in infrastructure, manufacturing, and technology will directly translate into 'new jobs, good jobs, with rising incomes'?
cqs.label: Invalid

cqs.reason: This question delves into the core of the argument by asking for specific actions and their expected outcomes, challenging the speaker's vague promises.
cqs.cq: What specific measures does Clinton propose to 'make the economy fairer,' and how will these measures address the root causes of economic inequality?
cqs.label: Invalid

cqs.reason: This question challenges the speaker's assertion that the economy will work for everyone by asking for concrete metrics and accountability measures.
cqs.cq: What metrics will be used to measure the success of the proposed investments and policies, and how will these metrics ensure that the economy works for everyone, not just those at the top?
cqs.label: Invalid

TRUMP_99.intervention:
TRUMP: "I will release them as soon as the audit
I 've been under audit almost for 15 years
I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited
I said , do you get audited
do you get audited
I get audited almost every year
in a way , I should be complaining
I 'm not even complaining
I do n't mind it
It 's almost become a way of life
I get audited by the IRS
But other people don't
We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of
I will release my tax returns—against my lawyer 's wishes—when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted
As soon as she releases them , I will release
I will release my tax returns
that 's against—my lawyers
they say , `` Do n't do it . '' I will tell you this
No—in fact , watching shows , they 're reading the papers
Almost every lawyer says , you do n't release your returns until the audit 's complete
When the audit 's complete , I 'll do it
I would go against them if she releases her e-mails"

cqs.reason: This question challenges the speaker's reasoning for linking two unrelated issues and demands evidence for the equivalence.
cqs.cq: Why should the release of Hillary Clinton's emails be a precondition for releasing your tax returns, and what evidence supports the equivalence of these two actions?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question delves into the core of the argument by asking for evidence to support the claim about the tax system and its relation to the release of tax returns.
cqs.cq: What specific evidence supports the claim that Trump's frequent audits are indicative of a broader issue in the tax system that needs to be addressed, and how does this relate to the fairness or necessity of releasing his tax returns?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question challenges the speaker's assertion about his lawyers' advice and weighs it against the public's right to know, which is central to the argument.
cqs.cq: What legal or ethical grounds do your lawyers have for advising against the release of your tax returns, and how do these grounds compare to the public's right to know about the financial dealings of a presidential candidate?
cqs.label: Unhelpful

TRUMP_174_1.intervention:
TRUMP: "I would love to respond
I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama
You treated him with terrible disrespect
I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are
It does n't work that way
You were after him
you were trying to—you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb , very famous pictures
I do n't think you can deny that
just last week , your campaign manager said it was true
when you tried to act holier than thou , it really does n't work
as far as the lawsuit , yes , when I was very young , I went into my father 's company , had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens , and we , along with many , many other companies throughout the country—it was a federal lawsuit—were sued
We settled the suit with zero—with no admission of guilt
It was very easy to do
I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.reason: This question challenges the relevance of past debates to the current context and examines the assumptions made about Clinton's character.
cqs.cq: How does the mention of past debates and the treatment of Barack Obama by Clinton relate to the current debate, and what assumptions are being made about Clinton's character based on these past actions?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question seeks specific evidence to support Trump's claims and compares the treatment of Obama to Trump, challenging the consistency of Clinton's behavior.
cqs.cq: What specific instances of 'terrible disrespect' did Trump witness during the debates between Clinton and Obama, and how do these instances compare to the treatment Trump received from Clinton?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question delves into the legal implications of the lawsuit settlement and challenges the assumption that settling without admission of guilt equates to innocence.
cqs.cq: How does the settlement of a federal lawsuit with 'no admission of guilt' necessarily imply innocence, and what evidence supports the claim that the lawsuit was unfairly brought against Trump and other companies?
cqs.label: Useful

when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also

CLINTON_244_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.reason: This question challenges Clinton's assumption that she speaks on behalf of the majority and seeks evidence to support her claim, which is central to her argument.
cqs.cq: How does Clinton ensure that the majority of the American people agree with her stance on honoring mutual defense treaties, and what evidence supports this claim?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question directly challenges Clinton's assertions about Trump's potential actions and seeks specific evidence, which is relevant to the debate on foreign policy.
cqs.cq: What specific evidence does Clinton have that Donald Trump would have started a war or bombed Iran, and how does this relate to the reliability of Trump's foreign policy proposals?
cqs.label: Useful

cqs.reason: This question asks for concrete proposals and comparisons, which are crucial for evaluating Clinton's stance on international relations and her opponent's.
cqs.cq: What specific actions or policies does Clinton propose to reassure allies in Japan and South Korea, and how do these actions differ from those of her opponent?
cqs.label: Useful
